title: 104_hr1521
content: The Act titled "Domestic Violence Identification and Referral Act of 1995" establishes provisions for domestic violence in certain health professions programs. The "Domestic Violence Identification and Referral Act of 1995" amends Section 791 of the Public Health Service Act to give preference to health professions entities that require training in identifying victims of domestic violence when awarding grants or contracts. The "Domestic Violence Identification and Referral Act of 1995" emphasizes the importance of health professionals in identifying and treating victims of domestic violence. It requires maintaining complete medical records, providing medical advice, and referring victims to appropriate services. The "Domestic Violence Identification and Referral Act of 1995" requires health professions entities like schools of medicine, nursing, and programs for physician assistants to report to Congress on the training hours provided for identifying and treating domestic violence victims. The "Domestic Violence Identification and Referral Act of 1995" mandates health professions entities to report on training hours for identifying and treating domestic violence victims, including definitions of domestic violence and preferences for training programs. The Secretary gives preference to entities that require students to have training in identifying and treating domestic violence victims as a condition for receiving a degree or certificate. This includes maintaining medical records, documenting examinations and treatments, and recording injuries. The Domestic Violence Identification and Referral Act of 1995 requires health professionals to provide medical advice on domestic violence, refer victims to relevant services, and report to Congress within 2 years of enactment. Health professions entities specified include schools of nursing and eligible public or nonprofit private entities. The Secretary must report to Congress on health professions entities receiving preference under the Domestic Violence Identification and Referral Act of 1995, including training hours, clinical experience, and types of courses provided. Definitions of domestic violence include various forms of abuse such as sexual assault, spousal abuse, and child abuse.
